'Harus Punya Skill': Suka-Duka Mencari Kerja di Australia Barat
06 Nov 2019, 02:02 by ABC
Setelah berkali-kali melamar kerja di berbagai restoran di Kota Perth, Australia Barat, Novie Collier akhirnya memutuskan untuk membuka usaha kue. Kini dia sibuk memenuhi pesanan pelanggan, apalagi saat-saat menjelang musim Natal seperti sekarang.
Novie datang ke Australia sejak tahun 2009 dan menikah dengan seorang warga setempat. Suaminya kini bekerja sebagai masinis pada perusahaan kereta api.
"Setelah menjadi PR, saya ikut belajar di TAFE. Tadinya mau mengambil kursus hospitality tapi bayarnya sangat mahal saat itu," katanya.
Sejak datang ke Perth, Novie mengaku tidak ingin tinggal diam di rumah dan bergantung pada penghasilan suaminya saja.


Novie Collier, warga asal Indonesia di Australia Barat, kini menjalankan usaha membuat kue. Salah satu kreasinya berupa kue bermotif batik. Kiriman: Istimewa

"Saya telah melamar berbagai kerjaan di restoran. Tapi lebih banyak ditolak," ujar Novie kepada jurnalis ABC Farid M. Ibrahim, Rabu (6/11/2019).
Tak berputus asa, Novie kemudian mengambil kursus membuat kue dan setelah selesai, dia pun mengurus izin ke Council (pemerintah setempat) untuk membuka usaha kue.
"Saya membuat segala macam kue, mulai dari kue ultah hingga kue-kue untuk Natal. Pokoknya kalau musim Natal, banyak sekali yang pesan," ujarnya.
Selama menjalankan usahanya ini, Novie mengaku pernah dua kali dihubungi pihak berwenang, menanyakan apakah usaha ini memenuhi aturan atau tidak.
"Mereka menghubungi saya katanya karena ada yang menyampaikan mengenai usaha saya ini. Tapi mereka justru mengatakan tidak usah khawatir karena semua aturan dipenuhi," katanya.
Di Indonesia, Novie pernah bekerja sebagai direktur salah satu perusahaan furnitur yang berada di Jepara. Dia bekerja di sana selama 10 tahun.
Kemudian dia pindah ke Bali dan mengurusi perusahaan Perancis yang membuat sarana skate park selama enam tahun.
"Saat itu saya banyak membantu urusan legal dan dokumen perusahaan-perusahaan penanaman modal asing (PMA) yang ada di Indonesia," jelasnya.
Kualifikasi Pekerja Migran
Kisah seperti Novie ini ternyata dialami oleh banyak migran atau pendatang di Australia. Hari Jumat (1/11/2019) lalu, riset terbaru yang dilakukan Bankwest Curtin Economics Centre di Australia Barat mengungkapkan sekitar 715 ribu migran bekerja di bidang yang tak sesuai kualifikasinya saat masih berada di negara asal.
Para migran yang mengalami dampak terburuk dari situasi ketidakcocokan kualifikasi ini umumnya berasal dari China, Jepang dan Korea.
Riset ini menemukan bahwa 48 persen migran dari negara-negara yang tidak berbahasa Inggris umumnya memiliki kualifikasi pendidikan tinggi.
Selain itu, mereka juga lebih banyak bergelar pascasarjana dan terus mengembangkan keterampilan tambahan begitu tiba di Australia.
Sementara migran dari negara-negara berbahasa Inggris, menurut riset ini, cenderung memiliki keterampilan yang sesuai dengan pekerjaan mereka.
Menurut laporan Sydney Morning Herald, Direktur Bankwest Curtin Economics Centre Alan Duncan menilai ketidakcocokan keterampilan ini berdampak pada rendahnya berpenghasilan sepertiga pekerja migran saat ini.
Duncan memperkirakan jika ketidakcocokan kualifikasi dan pekerjaan ini diatasi, maka hal itu akan meningkatkan ekonomi nasional sebesar 6 miliar setiap tahun.
"Jika kita ingin mewujudkan potensi ekonomi sepenuhnya, maka kita harus memanfaatkan keterampilan dan bakat semua warga Australia, termasuk para migran," katanya.
Bagi Novie Collier sendiri, anggapan bahwa di Australia itu gampang mencari kerja merupakan anggapan yang tidak sepenuhnya benar.
"Intinya orang di sini harus punya skill," ujarnya.

'Must Have Skills': Joy and Sorrow in Search of Work in Western Australia
Nov 6, 2019, 02:02 by ABC
After repeatedly applying for work in various restaurants in the City of Perth, Western Australia, Novie Collier finally decided to open a cake business. Now he is busy fulfilling customer orders, especially the time before the Christmas season like now.
Novie came to Australia since 2009 and married a local resident. Her husband now works as a train driver at a railroad company.
"After becoming a homework, I joined studying at TAFE. I was going to take a hospitality course but paid very expensive at that time," he said.
Since coming to Perth, Novie claimed she did not want to stay at home and depend on her husband's income.


Novie Collier, a citizen from Indonesia in Western Australia, now runs a cake-making business. One of his creations in the form of batik-patterned cake. Posts: Special

"I have applied for various jobs in restaurants. But more was rejected," Novie told ABC journalist Farid M. Ibrahim, Wednesday (11/06/2019).
Not giving up, Novie then took a cake-making course and after finishing, he also took care of permission to the Council (local government) to open a cake business.
"I make all kinds of cakes, ranging from birthday cakes to cookies for Christmas. The point is that during the Christmas season, lots of people order," he said.
During his business, Novie claimed he had been contacted twice by the authorities, asking whether this business met the rules or not.
"They contacted me, he said, because someone told me about my business. But they just said not to worry because all the rules were fulfilled," he said.
In Indonesia, Novie worked as a director of a furniture company located in Jepara. He worked there for 10 years.
Then he moved to Bali and managed a French company that made skate park facilities for six years.
"At that time I helped a lot of legal matters and documents of foreign investment companies (PMA) in Indonesia," he explained.
Migrant Worker Qualifications
Stories like Novie are apparently experienced by many migrants or migrants in Australia. Last Friday (1/11/2019), the latest research conducted by the Bankwest Curtin Economics Center in Western Australia revealed that around 715 thousand migrants worked in areas that were not in accordance with their qualifications while still in their home countries.
Migrants who experience the worst effects of this qualification mismatch situation generally come from China, Japan and Korea.
This research found that 48 percent of migrants from non-English speaking countries generally have higher education qualifications.
In addition, they also hold more postgraduate degrees and continue to develop additional skills once they arrive in Australia.
While migrants from English-speaking countries, according to this research, tend to have skills that are appropriate to their work.
According to the Sydney Morning Herald report, Bankwest Director Curtin Economics Center Alan Duncan assessed that this skill mismatch has an impact on the current low income of a third migrant worker.
Duncan estimates that if this mismatch of qualifications and work is overcome, it will increase the national economy by 6 billion every year.
"If we want to realize full economic potential, then we must utilize the skills and talents of all Australians, including migrants," he said.
For Novie Collier himself, the notion that in Australia it is easy to find work is an assumption that is not entirely true.
"The point is that people here must have skills," he said.
